messages.text:
the reason ‚ÄúOne-Hot‚Äù is a preferable name is that it is a triple entendre:
1. One element is hot
2. Hot element is 1
3. that‚Äôs one hot vector :hot_face: :woozy_face:

root.text:
hilarious exchange with Alan and <@U67G3QRJM> and a question during their lecture.

Alan: ‚ÄúI love the name one hot vector. it‚Äôs much nicer than column of identity or basis vector.
Question: ‚ÄúIf One-Hot is such a good name why do we call it hat?‚Äù
David: ‚Äúit‚Äôs how the Americans pronounce it.‚Äù

<https://youtu.be/wZrVxbmX218>

messages.text: Let's not forget that this case was more about "are APIs copyrightable" than about Google actually copying code or not

elements.text: Let's not forget that this case was more about "are APIs copyrightable" than about Google actually copying code or not

messages.text:
Not a lawyer, etc., but have been following this case a bit, so my (possibly flawed) summary:

Previous decisions in this series of cases decided that APIs _are_ copyrightable. However, the current supreme court decision says that writing code that reimplements and/or conforms to that API is not necessarily an infringement of that copyright (i.e., is _fair use_), even if it leads to virtually identical code, because by the nature of APIs, there are a bunch of things where there is really only one way to do it. Or in legal-speak

> Held:  Google‚Äôs  copying  of  the  Java  SE  API,  which  included  only  those  lines of code that were needed to allow programmers to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program, was a fair use of that material as a matter of law.

root.text: Any lawyers here that can explain like I'm 5?

elements.text: Any lawyers here that can explain like I'm 5?

Not a lawyer, etc., but have been following this case a bit, so my (possibly flawed) summary:

Previous decisions in this series of cases decided that APIs
are
copyrightable. However, the current supreme court decision says that writing code that reimplements and/or conforms to that API is not necessarily an infringement of that copyright (i.e., is
fair use
), even if it leads to virtually identical code, because by the nature of APIs, there are a bunch of things where there is really only one way to do it. Or in legal-speak

Held:  Google‚Äôs  copying  of  the  Java  SE  API,  which  included  only  those  lines of code that were needed to allow programmers to put their accrued talents to work in a new and transformative program, was a fair use of that material as a matter of law.

messages.text: Who here lives in Germany and is willing to chat with me? I want to get a feeling for how it would be to live in Germany for a bit. My wife has a German passport and speaks German as her first language (but has never lived there, only been for holiday). I specifically want to find out how tight our budget would be on my current salary (as a worst case single-income scenario) and all the other little things, like is it fun to live there, where should we aim for, how easy will we make friends, what is life like generally etc.

messages.text: <https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/JZZENevaLzLLeC3zn/predictive-coding-has-been-unified-with-backpropagation|Predictive coding has been unified with backpropagation>

attachments.title: Predictive Coding has been Unified with Backpropagation - LessWrong
attachments.text: Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) are based around the backpropagation algorithm. The backpropagation algorithm allows you to perform gradient descent on a network of neurons. When we feed training data through an ANNs, we use the backpropagation algorithm to tell us how the weights should change. ANNs are good at inference problems. Biological Neural Networks (BNNs) are good at inference too. ANNs are built out of neurons. BNNs are built out of neurons too. It makes intuitive sense that ANNs and BNNs might be running similar algorithms. There is just one problem: BNNs are physically incapable of running the backpropagation algorithm. We do not know quite enough about biology to say it is impossible for BNNs to run the backpropagation algorithm. However, "a consensus has emerged that the brain cannot directly implement backprop, since to do so would require biologically implausible connection rules"[1]. The backpropagation algorithm has three steps. 1. Flow information forward through a network to compute a prediction. 2. Compute an error by comparing the prediction to a target value. 3. Flow the error backward through the network to update the weights. The backpropagation algorithm requires information to flow forward and backward along the network. But biological neurons are one-directional. An action potential goes from the cell body down the axon to the axon terminals to another cell's dendrites. An axon potential never travels backward from a cell's terminals to its body. HEBBIAN THEORY Predictive coding is the idea that BNNs generate a mental model of their environment and then transmit only the information that deviates from this model. Predictive coding considers error and surprise to be the same thing. Hebbian theory is specific mathematical formulation of predictive coding. Predictive coding is biologically plausible. It operates locally. There are no separate prediction and training phases which must be synchronized. Most importantly, it lets
attachments.fallback: Predictive Coding has been Unified with Backpropagation - LessWrong

elements.text: Predictive coding has been unified with backpropagation

messages.text: Any latex/typography expert around here? I'm trying to figure out the integral symbol in unicode fonts. There are two different ones, the small one for inline math (U+222B) and the big (glorious) one for separate equations, but I can't figure out where is the latter located in the font set (currently New Computer Modern). Context: trying to implement a simple TeX engine to have nice math symbols in Makie.

elements.text: Any latex/typography expert around here? I'm trying to figure out the integral symbol in unicode fonts. There are two different ones, the small one for inline math (U+222B) and the big (glorious) one for separate equations, but I can't figure out where is the latter located in the font set (currently New Computer Modern). <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/sinc-interpolation-based-on-fft/52512/75>

attachments.title: Sinc Interpolation based on FFT
attachments.text: Yes, the Nyquist component is ambiguous in this sense, but there are ways to disambiguate. For example, for a band-limited signal there is a unique choice that minimizes the mean-square slope of the interpolated function, and the same choice also has the nice property of giving a real interpolant from real inputs. I have some notes on this: <https://math.mit.edu/~stevenj/fft-deriv.pdf>
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: Sinc Interpolation based on FFT

messages.text: Asked for a collaborative editor solution with Julia support; some people here recommended VS Code Live, which we now tried out. In principle it seems OK-ish, but a major bummer so far was the weird "follow focus" behavior. E.g. I press "return" to insert a newline, and WHAM the view jumps somewhere (I suspect: where the other user is looking at?). I found a command to "follow user", which I think means we follow their cursor and/or view... but I found no way to "unfollow" / to simply keep my editor view centered on my own cursor... Is this normal? Anybody got a hint what to do about this?

elements.text: Asked for a collaborative editor solution with Julia support; some people here recommended VS Code Live, which we now tried out. In principle it seems OK-ish, but a major bummer so far was the weird "follow focus" behavior. E.g. I press "return" to insert a newline, and WHAM the view jumps somewhere (I suspect: where the other user is looking at?). I found a command to "follow user", which I think means we follow their cursor and/or view... but I found no way to "unfollow" / to simply keep my editor view centered on my own cursor... Is this normal? Anybody got a hint what to do about this?

messages.text:
A non-Julia advice but I believe people can guide better:-

I want to get into data science but the maths(stats and prob) confuses me a lot. I have theoretical knowledge instead of practical knowledge 

I know little bit of stats from school but there's a serious disconnect in applicability of that Maths in real world problem solving 

Also, I don't want to study data science from engineer's point of view 

I want to learn to learn data science from a marketing or sales  point of view....so I can solve real world marketing and sales problems for companies 

I'm confused where should I start learning Maths for data science. I don't want to study masters in DS(can't afford it also not a fan of college education). I have couple of math resources in mind(3blue1brown, khan academy, open stax stats and business books)

I'm literally confused where to begin with and my what would my complete learning journey look like?

messages.text:
Convo thread:
We sit in front of a computer to do work/research for a Lot of Time Every Day, and with an internet connection to :infinity: amount of possible distractions.
How have you found ways to stay focused?

attachments.title: JuliaSim - Simulating Reality (upcoming product by Julia Computing)
attachments.text: JuliaSim: Simulating Reality Coming soon: JuliaSim is a next generation cloud-based simulation platform, combining the latest techniques in SciML with equation-based digital twin modeling and simulation. Surrogatize your models, use pre-accelerated models from the thousands of available models, generate digital twins from data, and more. Bringing Julia to Industrial Scale Modeling and Simulation JuliaSim allows you to directly import models from its Model Store into your Julia environment, ma...

messages.text: Taking the name of this channel literally, are there any vectorized RNGs in Julia? <https://github.com/lemire/SIMDxorshift|Here> in one in C. I find that often operations that might be vectorized are bottlenecked by the serial nature of RNGs, producing just a stream of random floats.

elements.text: Taking the name of this channel literally, are there any vectorized RNGs in Julia?
Here
in one in C. I find that often operations that might be vectorized are bottlenecked by the serial nature of RNGs, producing just a stream of random floats.

messages.text: Anyone have experiences with email providers with custom domain support? I'm on ProtonMail currently but would like to move to something that supports other email apps (PM requires a bridge app on desktop to do the encryption and locks you into their app on mobile). So far FastMail seems like a good alternative.

elements.text: Anyone have experiences with email providers with custom domain support? I'm on ProtonMail currently but would like to move to something that supports other email apps (PM requires a bridge app on desktop to do the encryption and locks you into their app on mobile). So far FastMail seems like a good alternative.

messages.text: I‚Äôve been using VectorizedRNG.jl for a while ‚Äî it‚Äôs fast and just works!

root.text: Taking the name of this channel literally, are there any vectorized RNGs in Julia? <https://github.com/lemire/SIMDxorshift|Here> in one in C. I find that often operations that might be vectorized are bottlenecked by the serial nature of RNGs, producing just a stream of random floats.

elements.text: Taking the name of this channel literally, are there any vectorized RNGs in Julia?
Here
in one in C. I find that often operations that might be vectorized are bottlenecked by the serial nature of RNGs, producing just a stream of random floats.
I‚Äôve been using VectorizedRNG.jl for a while ‚Äî it‚Äôs fast and just works!

messages.text: Is anyone else too scared to comment on a github issue some times? I recently tried to help with some debugging, on a code base I have no idea about. I am quite certain what I commented may be obvious/wrong and now I feel like that comment will be there for eternity and my stupidity is archived for posterity.

attachments.title: TUI 737 weight incident traced to ‚ÄòMiss‚Äô interpretation of female passengers
attachments.text: Investigators have traced a take-off weight error on a TUI Airways Boeing 737-800 to a flaw introduced to a reservations system by international differences in the manner that female passengers are addressed. The reservations system had been upgraded during a period in which TUI Airways operations were suspended as a ...

messages.text:
The UK royal family announced that HRH Prince Philip passed away this morning. As someone who just passed the UK citizenship test, I'm probably obliged to fly the flag at half staff now. Ninety-nine... as my grandfather would have said, "not a bad innings".

|
|
|
|:flag-gb:
|
|
|

messages.text: work can be _fun_ or _useful_. i try to avoid doing work that is neither fun nor useful, so by <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berkson%27s_paradox|berkson's paradox>, I will observe a negative correlation between fun and useful work

messages.text: <https://twitter.com/pyblogsal/status/1380516575485263873|https://twitter.com/pyblogsal/status/1380516575485263873> it'd be great to have someone going through a similar effort in Julia to improve error messages where possible

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/pyblogsal|@pyblogsal>: Python educators and users: I have been working on improving SyntaxError messages in CPython lately. What error (only *SyntaxErrors* for now :sweat_smile:) messages you or your students have struggle with? Which ones you think we should improve? :thinking_face: (Pls RT to help reaching more people :pray:).
